content.webTitle: The Missing – surely the most grisly, gripping show on television

fields.headline: The Missing – surely the most grisly, gripping show on television
fields.bodyText: • Spoiler alert: this blog was published after The Missing aired on Wednesday 9 November. Do not read on unless you have watched the fifth episode. If, after the latest episode of The Missing, you can still look in the toolbox and contemplate putting up a picture with that Black and Decker drill, you’re made of stronger stuff than me. Poor sweet German copper Lenhart met an incredibly gruesome end at the hands of corrupt soldier Gettrick. Having deduced that there was a third man involved in the widening child abduction ring, and naively popping round to ask Gettrick about his part in it, young Lenhart ended up coming undone. At Gettrick’s house, he met a little girl we can assume is the child of Gettrick (or Stone Sr) and Sophie Giroux – if it is indeed Sophie Giroux and not Alice Webster, or the third girl spotted in the rollercoaster pictures. It’s complicated. By sheer coincidence and miraculous timing, the child happened to be awake, and walking downstairs, and to have drawn a picture of herself with her mother “in the basement”, which she happily explained to Lenhart, clicking the story in to place. Unfortunately Gettrick stopped it going any further by doing a bit of DIY on Lenhart’s brain (I assume it was his brain – I closed my eyes as soon as the drill started to whirr). If you thought the end of the last episode was a shocker – is that Sophie/Alice having a coffee in Switzerland in the present day? – this upped the ante. Not since Lisa Faulkner got her head dunked in a vat of boiling oil in the very first episode of Spooks has an on-screen murder seemed so grisly. And there are still three episodes left, and plenty of questions to answer. Will Baptiste crack one last case before he shuffles off this mortal coil? Where is the third girl? Will the Websters learn what happened to their daughter? Is there any chance she could still be alive? What of the framed butcher and his ex-military wife? Could a child reared in a kidnap bunker be any more capable of perfect dramatic timing? And just how much did the army cover up? Doubtless there are more. It’s been so twisty, so good at shattering our expectations, that at times I’ve had to wind back, just to work out who was doing what to whom. Its ambition and boldness in telling a complex story without pandering to the fact that you might need a bit of time to comprehend it all has paid off. Plus it’s a pleasure to watch truly incredible actors performing as if their Bafta depended on it, particularly Tchéky Karyo as the Sara Lund-esque Baptiste, and Keeley Hawes as Alice’s mother Gemma, who, after her Line of Duty performance earlier this year, deserves a special award for her contribution to the portrayal of steely yet harrowed women on the BBC. The Missing’s first series, which starred James Nesbitt as the father of an abducted boy, was a huge success for creators the Williams brothers, pulling in almost nine million viewers for the season finale. The latest run shows their schtick is no one-trick-pony. It’s proven to be one of those outstanding BBC dramas that makes all the mega-budgets of huge US shows seem unnecessary. Over multiple countries and languages and time frames, and with just eight lean episodes, this is elegant, bleak television, redolent of peak Scandi-noir thrillers like The Killing and The Bridge. It might not have been pleasant to uncover this frozen world of military cover-ups, murders and child abduction, but it has been gripping from the start. I just dread to think what they’ll do with a spirit level before we get to the end.
